metadata.case_name: Assessee Bank v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The assessee is a Bank carrying on banking business.

For the assessment year 1945-46, assessable income computed by Income Tax Officer at Rs. 14,95,826 by splitting income into interest on securities Rs. 23,62,815 and business loss Rs. 8,86,972; net income after adjustments Rs. 14,95,826.
In the previous year, there was a loss of Rs. 3,21,929 computed by setting off business loss against interest on securities.

Assessee claimed entitlement to set off carried over loss of previous year against profits of 1945-46 under s.24(2) on basis that dealing in securities is part of banking business and no distinction between income from securities and business income.
Income Tax Officer rejected claim as loss under business head and refused set-off under s.24(2).
On appeal to Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, contention repeated that assessee is dealer in securities, two heads part of same business; contention repelled.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that ss.6,8,10 require keeping income from two sources separate; refused set-off of previous year business loss against current year income from securities.
Assessee applied for reference to High Court raising questions including whether interest on securities part of bank's business income and entitlement to set-off carried over loss.

Tribunal referred three questions to Calcutta High Court: (1) entitlement to set-off business loss Rs.3,21,929 against interest on securities; (2) deduction of administrative expenses under s.8; (3) deduction of interest on borrowed money for tax-free securities under first proviso to s.8.
Calcutta High Court answered all questions in negative; judgment dated May 18, 1953.
High Court Chief Justice held heads under s.6 mutually exclusive; interest on securities cannot be treated as business income.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate from High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether interest on securities held by a bank as trading assets falls under s.8 or s.10 of the Indian Income-tax Act.
Whether assessee entitled to set off carried over business loss from previous year against income from interest on securities in assessment year under s.24(2).
Whether heads of income under s.6 are mutually exclusive.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ss.8 and 10 should be read so that interest on securities as trading assets excluded from s.8 and falls under business head s.10; alternatively s.10 more appropriate.
If ss.8 and 10 equally applicable, assessee has option to be taxed under head imposing lighter burden.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bosotto Bros.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if heads mutually exclusive, interest on securities and business profits result from different operations of same banking business; entitled to set-off under s.24(2).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.24(2); Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

petitioner_arguments.text: Securities part of trading assets accepted by Department; income from banking business including securities one source under s.10.

respondent_arguments.text: Heads under s.6 mutually exclusive; interest on securities falls specifically under s.8 regardless of trading or capital asset.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: ss.6,8,10; Probhat Chandra Barua v. The King Emperor

respondent_arguments.text: S.24(2) allows set-off only against profits of same business under s.10; not against s.8 income.
Form of return under s.22(1) shows separate heads; supports exclusivity.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of Act: s.6 enumerates mutually exclusive heads; ss.7-12 provide computation for each; income from whatever source falls under one specific head.
Interest on securities taxable under s.8 whether trading asset or capital; specific head prevails over business head s.10.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.8 applies to all interest on securities; amendment to proviso supports this.

court_reasoning.text: No option for assessee or Revenue to choose head; specific head governs.
On set-off under s.24(2): No finding whether holding securities part of same business as banking; unnecessary to decide in view of proposed order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Requires finding on 'same business'; absent here.

holdings.text: Heads of income under s.6 mutually exclusive; interest on securities falls under specific head s.8, not s.10 even if held as trading assets by bank.
No set-off of business loss against interest on securities without finding that securities part of same business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Probhat Chandra Barua v. The King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: S.6 is charging section; heads mutually exclusive.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
Chatturam v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar

precedents_cited.relevance: Schedules mutually exclusive; income under one cannot be under another.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Chunilal Mehta
precedents_cited.relevance: S.6 classifies sources distinctly; business distinct from investment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Butler v. The Mortgage Company of Egypt Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Specific provision for securities prevails even in business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thompson v. The Trust and Loan Company of Canada
precedents_cited.relevance: Income with own tax character cannot be reclassified.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commercial Properties Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Income from property not business even if company purpose.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.C. Kothari v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: S.8 separate head; no change to another head.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bosotto Bros.
precedents_cited.relevance: Option only if heads overlap equally; not here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab
Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ahmuty & Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Dividends for share dealers under s.10, but not analogous.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Messrs. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: New points within framed question allowable.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Heads of income mutually exclusive; computation under specific sections; set-off provisions.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's view that interest on securities is taxable exclusively under s.8, not s.10, even for a bank holding them as trading assets; declined to opine on set-off under s.24(2) absent finding on 'same business'; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "Reading ss. 6, 8 and 10 it appears to us that the legislature wanted to keep the income from the two sources as separate."
key_quotes.speaker: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal

key_quotes.text: "It appears to me, therefore, that because the several heads under s. 6 in the Indian Act are mutually exclusive... interest on securities in the hands of a banker cannot be treated as business income."
key_quotes.speaker: High Court Chief Justice

key_quotes.text: "The various heads of income, profits and gains have been so classified that the items falling under those heads become chargeable under ss. 7 to 12 according as they are income of which the source is salaries, interest on securities..."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Income derived by a trading company from investments of its funds... in government securities must be taxed under Sch. C, and cannot... be brought into account."
key_quotes.speaker: Lord Atkin in Salisbury House Estate v. Fry

key_quotes.text: "A banker could never ask to be repaid the tax which had been deducted from the Government securities which he held, because he held them as a banker..."
key_quotes.speaker: Rowlatt J. in Butler v. Mortgage Company
